unnormalised: The bustling Crawford Market in Mumbai was abuzz as usual this morning. But the usual haggling over prices felt a little different. It wasn't just the usual dance between seller and buyer; the numbers themselves seemed to carry more weight.
normalised: The bustling Crawford Market in Mumbai was abuzz as usual this morning. But the usual haggling over prices felt a little different. It was not just the usual dance between seller and buyer; the numbers themselves seemed to carry more weight.

unnormalised: “Rs. 250 for a kilo of mangoes?” exclaimed Priya Sharma, a regular shopper, as she surveyed the fruit. Just yesterday, she’d bought the same mangoes for Rs. 220. The vendor, a seasoned market veteran, simply shrugged. “Madam, petrol prices went up. Everything costs more now." He pointed to the board displaying the day's vegetable prices. "Bhindi is ₹80/kg, up from ₹70 last week. Even the coriander leaves went from Rs. 10 to Rs. 15 per bunch!”
normalised: “Rupees two hundred and fifty for a kilogram of mangoes?” exclaimed Priya Sharma, a regular shopper, as she surveyed the fruit. Just yesterday, she’d bought the same mangoes for Rupees two hundred and twenty. The vendor, a seasoned market veteran, simply shrugged. “Madam, petrol prices went up. Everything costs more now." He pointed to the board displaying the day's vegetable prices. "Bhindi is rupee eighty per kilogram, up from rupee seventy last week. Even the coriander leaves went from Rupees ten to Rupees fifteen per bunch!”

unnormalised: The ripple effect of inflation was evident everywhere. Auto-rickshaw fares to the market had climbed by ₹5, and even a simple cup of chai at the nearby stall cost Rs. 12, up from Rs. 10. It's not just the big spenders feeling the pinch, but also the average person trying to buy their daily essentials.
normalised: The ripple effect of inflation was evident everywhere. Auto-rickshaw fares to the market had climbed by rupee five, and even a simple cup of chai at the nearby stall cost Rupees twelve, up from Rupees ten. It is not just the big spenders feeling the pinch, but also the average person trying to buy their daily essentials.

unnormalised: Across the city at Linking Road, a different scenario played out. A trendy boutique advertised a "Monsoon Sale" with discounts of up to 50% on select items. A sign outside read, "Kurtis from Rs. 800 onwards!". Isha Khan, browsing through the racks, sighed. Even with the discount, a simple cotton kurta cost Rs. 1200. “These prices are still way too high,” she muttered to her friend.
normalised: Across the city at Linking Road, a different scenario played out. A trendy boutique advertised a "Monsoon Sale" with discounts of up to fifty percent on select items. A sign outside read, "Kurtis from Rupees eight hundred onwards!". Isha Khan, browsing through the racks, sighed. Even with the discount, a simple cotton kurta cost Rupees one thousand two hundred. “These prices are still way too high,” she muttered to her friend.

unnormalised: Whether at the chaotic Crawford Market or the fashionable Linking Road, the same story unfolded: every rupee counted, and the rising cost of living was making every purchase a carefully considered decision.
